results.title: Hiroshima mon amour
results.creator_credit: Argos Films, Como Films, Pathe Overseas, Daiei Motion Picture Company, Sacha Kamenka, Shirakawa Takeo, Samy Halfron and Alain Resnais
results.brief_description: A French actress, in Hiroshima to take part in a film about peace, has a brief affair with a Japanese man. As they discuss the horror and consequences of the nuclear destruction of the city, the woman slowly, hesitantly begins to reveal the story of her own individual horror when she was punished for loving a German soldier during World war II. Combining footage of the destruction of Hiroshima, the film eschews linear narrative and instead moves back and forth between the past and present, exploring the effects of memory and trauma. Scripted by novelist Marguerite Duras, “Hiroshima Mon Amour” heralded a new phase for international cinema, a precursor to the New Wave, and the development of a cinema that would explore contemporary questions of philosophy and politics. Though the “stories” which the film explores are powerfully involving, the formal structure of the film forces the viewer to confront his or her own personal construction of “memory” as mediated through film and history. The film shows the impossibility of “explaining” Hiroshima but also convincingly explores the need to permanently interrogate the conditions which led to Hiroshima.

results.title: Highlander [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Highlander Productions, Peter S. Davis, William N Panzer and Russell Mulcahy
results.brief_description: From the dawn of time there has been the immortals, destined to live forever and compete for the ultimate prize, duelling against one another until there is only one left with power beyond imagination. Only decapitation can end their immortality. Set in contemporary Manhatten, this fantasy saga follows Highlander Connor Macleod (Christopher Lambert) in a battle against his eternal enemy and main contender for the prize, The Kurgan (Clancy Brown). After being arrested by the police for a fracas in an underground carpark which results in a headless body, Connor must also contend with the inundation of questions, and challenge the notion that immortals cannot fall in love. Connor discovers he is one of the immortals when he is “killed” during a battle in the Scottish highlands by The Kurgan, but miraculously does not die. He learns of his status by fellow immortal Ramirez (Sean Connery), who must cede his immortality by decapitation to make way for a superior contender to battle for the prize. This cult classic makes effective use of flashbacks between past and present and spawned many less superior sequels. Cast includes also Roxanne Hart, Beatie Edney and Alan North. Soundtrack by Queen.

results.title: High tide
results.brief_description: Lilli (Judy Davis) is back-up singer for an Elvis Presley imitator (Frankie J. Holden) and living an aimless life on the edge of show business. She is strong minded and independent. She is also alone and lost, drifting to escape commitment. When Lilli is kicked out of her act she finds herself stranded in a coastal town with a broken down car, no money, no job and nowhere to go. Through a strange twist of fate she befriends a teenage surfie kid, Ally (Claudia Karvan) who is the daughter she abandoned as an infant who was raised by her grandmother, a gutsy stern survivor (Jan Adele). “High Tide” follows the painful reunion between mother and daughter with an unflinching and at times hurtful honesty.

results.title: High spirits
results.creator_credit: Vision pdg, Palace Pictures, Stephen Woolley, David Saunders and Neil Jordan
results.brief_description: A desperate Peter Plunkett (Peter O’Toole) endeavours to save his crumbling Irish ancestral castle threatened with foreclosure by turning it into a hotel with a difference. Peter and his loyal staff create a supernatural fantasy to lure American tourists. All hell breaks loose when Jack (Steve Guttenberg), a married American, falls in love with Mary (Daryl Hannah), a gorgeous ghost. This prompts the real ghosts of Plunkett castle to wreak havoc. An hilarious, ghoulish, supernatural farce with collapsing sets and wind machine action. Cast members complained that the producers crudely altered the original whimsical intentions of writer-director Neil Jordan. Cast includes Beverley D’Angelo, Liam Neeson, Peter Gallagher, Jennifer Tilly, Ray McAnally, Martin Ferrero, Donal McCann, Connie Booth, Liz Smith and Mary Coughlan.

results.title: High Sierra
results.creator_credit: Warner Bros Pictures, First National Pictures, Hal B Wallis and Raoul Walsh
results.brief_description: Newly released from prison, bank robber “Mad Dog” Roy Earle (Humphrey Bogart) agrees to one last caper, out of gratitude to an old gangland pal. However, Earle has changed after eight years in gaol. He is torn between his hard-boiled, brutal side and more caring, compassionate feelings, which ultimately cause his downfall. When getaway plans misfire, Earle flees to the High Sierras. In a defiant last stand he is trapped at 11,000 feet with an army of police waiting below.

results.title: High noon (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: United Artists Corporation, Stanley Kramer and Fred Zimmerman
results.brief_description: A retired marshall is forced to take up his badge and guns again when a killer he has sent to jail returns to town seeking revenge. The townspeople refuse to help and his new bride wants him to run away from the fight. The marshall meets the killer and his three accomplices at high noon in one of the most suspenseful and thrilling gunfights ever filmed. Cast includes Gary Cooper and Grace Kelly. Based on the story ‘The Tin star’ by John W. Cunningham.

results.title: High fidelity
results.creator_credit: Working Title Films, Tim Bevan, Rudd Simmons and Stephen Frears
results.brief_description: This cult retro-pop-classic based on the book by Nick Hornby takes the audience back to the pop culture of the 80’s. Enter the jaded Rob (John Cusack), owner of Championship Vinyl, a man in his late 30’s whose passion for music and Peter Pan approach to life has caught up with him. When present girlfriend, Laura (Iben Kjejle), leaves him, he names his top 5 most memorable break-ups. The audience is taken on a loop of youth culture as well as being offered a glimpse into the male view of matters of the heart. The film uses Rob’s side-kicks (the “musical moron twins”), Dick and Barry (played by Todd Louiso Jack Black respectively), to help play homage to the music scene, never faltering, the two pastiche’ musical obsession to new heights, peppering the film with their top 5’s and hilarious musical anecdotes and showdowns. With a guest appearance by Bruce Springsteen, the cast is well courted with actors including Tim Robbins, Joan Cusack, Lisa Bonet, Lili Taylor and Catherine Zeta-Jones. Video also includes a 6 minute interview with John Cusack about the making of the film.

results.title: High anxiety (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Crossbow Films and Mel Brooks
results.brief_description: ‘High Anxiety’ is a parody of, and a dedication to, the cinema of Alfred Hitchcock. Using the simple plot of a psychiatrist with a fear of heights who arrives to take up a top post as head of the Institute for the Very, Very Nervous, Mel Brooks uses a gamut of scatological, Freudian and slap-stick jokes to create hilarious parodies of famous scenes in ‘The Birds’, ‘Psycho’, ‘Vertigo’ et. al. Cast includes Cloris Leachman, Madeline Kahn and Harvey Korman. The script was co-written by Barry Levinson.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Twentieth Century-Fox Film Corporation, Crossbow Films and Mel Brooks

results.title: High and low = Tengoku to jigoku [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Toho Kabushiki Kaisha, Tomoyuki Tanaka, Ryuzo Kikushima and Akira Kurosawa
results.brief_description: In the first half a kidnapping takes place and a ransom is negotiated; the second half deals with the manhunt for the kidnapper. The Japanese title - Heaven and Hell - directly suggests exact opposites and more clearly encapsulates the theme. It begins in ‘Heaven’ - the apartment high over the city - and ends in ‘Hell’ - the alleyways of Yokohama. The first half is superficially theatrical in its refusal of conventional editing strategies but actually is notable for its subtle dramatic geometry involving permutations of position and composition afforded by the Scope screen. Multiple cameras were used to film long takes. The film suddenly opens out into an action-packed chase. Based on the novel “King’s Ransom” by Ed McBain. Cast includes Toshiro Mifune, Tatsuya Nakadai, Kyoko Kagawa. In Japanese with English subtitles.
